title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: On a dark March night of 1286, King Alexander rode along the rough cliffpath between Burntisland and Kinghorn on a horse that stumbled in thedarkness, and in the morning, on the rocks far down below, the greywaves lapped against the ashen dead face of a mighty king.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Aberdour, a village on the Frith of Forth, four miles westwards  from Burntisland, is situated on the confines of Donibristle and Aberdour, the respective domains of the Earls of Moray and Morton.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Burntisland (Forth Hotel), a summer resort of the inhabitants  of Edinburgh, stands on a promontory opposite Granton, and forms one of the stations of the Edinburgh, Perth, and Dundee Railway.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Granton is also one of the stations of the Edinburgh, Perth, and Dundee Railway, and betwixt it and Burntisland, on the opposite coast of Fife, is the principal ferry on the Frith of Forth.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The distant view to the north and north-west includes the coast of Fife, Donnibristle House (Earl of Moray's), Inchcolm, Burntisland, the Lomond, Ochil, and Highland Hills, including Damyat (near Stirling), Ben Lomond, and Benledi.

title: Edinburgh,
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Sncll^ blae^ ^^i^^y-^ and scow- thering^ are four of these significant vocables ; they are all words that carry a shiver with them ; and for my part, as I see them aligned before me on the page, I am persuaded that a big wind comes tearing over the Firth from Burntisland and the northern hills ; I think I can hear it howl in the chimney, and as I set my fice northwards, feel its smarting kisses on my cheek.
